resource.name: Police Active Warrants
resource.description:
This dataset represents all active warrants recorded by the Norfolk Police Department. Warrants can be searched by type of crime, demographics of persons involved and total number of outstanding warrants.  This dataset is updated daily.  

Note: this dataset does not contain any active warrants that could possibly:
•	jeopardize an ongoing investigation, or prosecution, or the safety of an individual, 
•	cause a suspect to flee or evade detection,
•	result in the destruction of evidence.
resource.attribution: Norfolk Police Department

resource.description: This dataset represents all arrests that occurred in the last 24 hours as recorded by the Norfolk Police Department.  This dataset is updated daily.

resource.name: Police Incident Reports
resource.description: This dataset contains incident reports recorded by the Norfolk Police Department that occurred over the last five years. Incidents can be searched by type, location, date and time of occurrence.  This dataset is updated daily.

resource.name: Permits and Inspections
resource.description: This dataset provides information about permits and their associated inspections, violations, and status information. Norfolk’s Development Service Center (DSC) issues building, plumbing, mechanical, electrical, fire, amusement, elevator, certificates of occupancy, and zoning permits.  The purpose of the DSC is to consolidate acquisition of permits to one central location within Norfolk City Hall for the convenience of customers. This dataset is updated daily.
resource.attribution: Phil Winslow; Codes Enforcement Team Lead, Department of City Planning

resource.name: Significant Trees
resource.description: Volunteers with the Norfolk Master Gardeners gather this data about significant trees in Norfolk.  The data collected about these trees includes diameter, height, canopy spread, general location and species.  The data is updated every five years.
resource.attribution: Steven Traylor, City Forester; Recreation, Parks & Open Space (Parks and Forestry Operations)

resource.name: Public Art
resource.description:
Public art is artwork in public locations where everyone can see and enjoy it.
Norfolk is among the great cities that use public art to inspire, educate, beautify and give character to public places. The Public Arts Commission together with city staff, developed policies for the development of artwork that creates a unique image and sense of place for Norfolk. This dataset is a compiled list of existing public art recorded by Norfolk. This data is updated annually.
*Please note this dataset does not include the Mermaid Statues.
resource.attribution: Marketing and Communications – Norfolk Arts

resource.name: American Rescue Plan Act State and Local Recovery Funds Project Status
resource.description: The city, through the American Rescue Plan Act (ARPA), is the direct recipient of $154,141,050 in State and Local Fiscal Recovery Funds (SLFRF). This dataset contains information on the status of City Council approved projects that were made possible by SLFRF. The data comes from the city’s financial system AFMS and city staff. The financial data will be updated daily based on activity in the city’s financial system, AFMS. The remaining data will be updated monthly.
resource.attribution: Department of Housing and Community Development

resource.name: Complaints
resource.description:
This dataset provides data from the City of Norfolk’s complaint tracking system. Complaints originate from calls by citizens to the Norfolk Cares Center or are staff reported. The Department of Neighborhood Services and the Department of City Planning address complaints by inspecting properties and, if applicable, notifying property owners of violations. The goal of pursuing compliance is to strengthen neighborhood standards and improve property safety. Types of complaints may include property issues such tall weeds and grass, trash and debris, abandoned vehicles, graffiti, parking in residential areas, and others. This dataset includes a rolling three years of data and will be updated daily.

Disclaimer: Unless otherwise indicated, presence in this dataset signifies only that a complaint has been made against the subject property. Presence within this dataset does not reflect any assessment by the City of Norfolk of whether or not the complaint accurately reflects the condition of the property and whether or not the condition of the property violates any applicable law.
resource.attribution: Department of Neighborhood Services; Department of City Planning
columns_description: A unique identifier assigned to the complaint for tracking and reference purposes.
A specific identifier for the parcel or land associated with the complaint within the City's grid system.
The tax account number linked to the property or parcel associated with the complaint for tax assessment purposes.
The physical location or street address to which the complaint is assigned.
The latitude of the parcel.
The longitude of the parcel.
The Ward that the parcel is within.
The Superward that the parcel is within.
If applicable, the Civic League that the parcel is within.
The date the complaint was created in the City of Norfolk’s complaint tracking system.
The date the complaint was last modified in the City of Norfolk’s complaint tracking system.
The date the complaint was closed.
The origin of the complaint, which is either reported by residents through Norfolk Cares or by City of Norfolk staff.
The current status of the complaint. Values include “Closed”, “Open”, “Closed – Unfounded”, “Completed with open violations”, “Closed – Completed with notes”, “Stop Work Order Issued”, and others.

The classification of the complaint. Values include “Nuisance”, “Housing/Structures”, “Property Use Issues”, “Working Without Permit”, “Property Line Concerns”, “Environmental”, “Short-Term Rental” and others.
The additional sub-classification of the complaint. Values include “Tall Grass & Weeds”, “Trash & Debris”, “Inoperable Vehicle”, “Exterior”, and others.
Indicates if the complaint triggered an inspection to be conducted at the property.
Lists the department that addressed or will address the complaint.

resource.name: Annual Expenditures
resource.description:
This dataset summarizes the city’s cash outlays and accruals for the cost of goods received or services rendered, by department, department unit/division, and expenditure type, for three years; the current fiscal year and two previous fiscal years. The city's fiscal year runs July 1 to June 30.  The city’s financial system, where transactions are recorded daily, is the source for this data. The data also contains current budget information. Current budget reflects budget transfers and amendments during the fiscal year that have transpired since City Council adopted the budget prior to the beginning of the current fiscal year.  The data is refreshed daily on weekdays, and the expenditure amounts are current as of the date it was last refreshed.  

*Disclaimer: Expenditures will reflect the previous fiscal year’s activity until final entries have been made and the accounting period has been closed.

This data is updated daily on weekdays.
resource.attribution: Emily Uselton, Interim Director; Department of Budget and Strategic Planning
columns_description: Name of the fund source for the expenditure
Total annual budgeted expenditures for this department/fund/unit/object line
Sum of fiscal year-to-date expenditures for this department/fund/unit/object line
Name of the responsible unit/division/bureau within the department
Description of the expenditure type
Fiscal year (FY) in which the expenditure took place; the city’s fiscal year runs from July 1 to June 30. For example, FY 2020 began on July 1, 2019 and will end on June 30, 2020.
Description of the expenditure category, such as personnel or contractual services
Department that is responsible for the expenditure

resource.name: Tide Sensors
resource.description:
This data is from five tide stations located in waterways throughout Norfolk: Elizabeth River Eastern Branch at Grandy Village, Little Creek at 20th Bay Street, Lafayette River at Mayflower Road, Mason Creek at Granby Street, and Elizabeth River Main Branch at Nauticus. This data will allow users to track and analyze tide levels in the City of Norfolk. The data is updated daily and encompasses a timeframe of September 30, 2020 to present.

Note: At the Mason Creek tide gauge, the water flows through a weir system (small dam) that alters the flow characteristics of the water; data from this tide station will differ from the other four tide stations.

Disclaimer: The City is making this data available with the understanding that it has not been reviewed or verified by an expert. Although the City makes every effort to ensure the tide gauges are accurate, we cannot guarantee the calibration or proper functioning of the gauges and accurate recording of measured tide levels at all times. In no event will the City of Norfolk be liable for any damages, including but not limited to loss or damage to property, lost profits, business interruption, loss of business information or other pecuniary loss that might arise from the use of this data. Any use of this data is for general information only and shall not be used for any improper purpose.
columns_name: Elizabeth River Eastern Branch at Grandy Village
Elizabeth River Main Branch at Nauticus
columns_description: The time in Norfolk of the reading
The Unix timestamp of the reading, used to avoid errors relating to Daylight Savings Time.
Tide height (ft) at Grandy Village (36.83975 , -76.25027)
Tide height (ft) at 20th Bay St (36.92551 , -76.19395)
Tide height (ft) at Mayflower Rd (36.88854 , -76.28518)
Tide height (ft) at Granby St (36.93147 , -76.26623). Water levels here are different than the others due to a weir system.
Tide height (ft) at Nauticus (36.84819 , -76.29336)

resource.name: Permits - Right of Way
resource.description:
The dataset contains information on permits issued by the Right of Way Management Division. The dataset contains open permits including: right of way excavations and installations, residential and commercial driveway entrances, general temporary parking, storage, and dumpsters, hauling oversize and cranes, and lane, street, and sidewalk closures. The dataset provides information on issue, start and end dates, applicant, work performed for, type and kind of permit, inspector, contact number, and geographic coordinates.  

This data is updated daily on weekdays.  

Click here for details on Right of Way permit fees:  https://www.norfolk.gov/DocumentCenter/View/789

Clich here for a map showing all permit activity locations: 
https://batchgeo.com/map/64a1948c2f9487b290d8f12f798b9859
resource.attribution: Freda Burns, Right of Way Administrator, Department of Public Works

resource.name: STORM | System to Track, Organize, Record, and Map
resource.description: This dataset provides an extract from Norfolk's STORM application.  STORM, an acronym for System to Track, Organize, Record and Map, captures data collected by residents and city staff during and after inclement weather events.  The app captures incidents such as flooded streets, damaged trees, disabled vehicles, downed cable lines, etc. This dataset provides a record of reported events entered into STORM beginning in 2010; the dataset is updated during and after weather events.
resource.attribution: Ken Creameans: City of Norfolk, Department of Information Technology

Longitude is the angular distance east or west on the earth's surface. Expressed either in degrees or by some corresponding difference in time.

resource.name: Neighborhood Quality Code Enforcement Cases
resource.description: This dataset provides data from the Norfolk Division of Neighborhood Quality’s code enforcement cases including associated inspections, violations and status.  The mission of the Division of Neighborhood Quality is to maintain and strengthen neighborhood standards. Staff use a variety of tools to achieve compliance including educating civic leagues, residents and the public about neighborhood quality.  Other tools include working with homeowners to establish timelines for projects or pursuing legal steps for abatement. This data reflects the workflow of a responsive customer-oriented organization.
resource.attribution: Sherry Johnson - Neighborhood Quality Division - Department of Neighborhood Development

resource.name: MyNorfolk
resource.description:
This dataset provides data from MyNorfolk, a citizen services portal that delegates and tracks requests and questions about the city of Norfolk and the services we provide to our residents, businesses, and visitors.  Data for the service requests is collected from phone calls, emails, an app for smart phones and on-line. The portal is managed by the Norfolk Cares Center; its mission is to provide a single point of contact for visitors, residents, businesses and city staff to request a city service, report a concern, seek information about Norfolk, or follow-up on a previous request for service.

**Disclaimer - With the current process in place, not all tickets are closed automatically. There could be tickets shown as open in this dataset that are closed in our other systems. We are working to address the issue.
resource.attribution: Halima Akar, Customer Service Manager, Norfolk Cares Center
columns_description: Service Request Identification Number
Date and Time of last update made to service request
Date and Time Record was created
Address of Service Request Concern
Current Status of Service Request
Service Request Issue
Department/Division Responsible for Completion of Service Request

resource.name: Litter Index
resource.description:
The Community Appearance Index, also known as the Litter Index, is a tool designed by Keep America Beautiful to visually evaluate the overall appearance of a community using litter as an indicator. Every year, 60 routes throughout the five wards of Norfolk are analyzed to determine the cleanliness of the city. After a thorough training, a team of volunteers conduct the analysis using a scoring system ranging from 1-4 with “1” indicating minimal to no litter and “4” indicating extremely littered. Methodology for this process includes recruiting volunteers who commit to attend a one-and-a-half-day Community Appearance Index scan. Each volunteer is thoroughly trained on the index to accurately and consistently survey a statistical sample of the city. The results of the scan are then averaged to produce the City of Norfolk Community Appearance Index score.

This dataset is updated annually; the data begins in 2010.  The Litter Index survey is normally conducted in August; the 2020 survey will be delayed due to COVID-19.
resource.attribution: Sarah Sterzing, Keep Norfolk Beautiful

resource.name: Emergency Communications 24-Hour Call Volume
resource.description:
This dataset shows all calls processed by emergency communications personnel in Norfolk, VA. The Emergency Communications Center is where calls are received from the public and then dispatched to public safety personnel (police, fire-rescue). The dataset shows daily (24-hour period of operations) calls and texts processed by emergency communications personnel. This dataset will be updated daily.

Please note: Data from April 5, 2023 to May 23, 2023 is not available due to equipment upgrades during this timeframe.
resource.attribution: Department of Emergency Preparedness and Response - Division of Emergency Communications

The Norfolk Cares data set provides data from the IMPACT System. The data was collected by phone calls, emails, iPhone requests, and on-line requests.  This data set includes service requests from November 2014 to October 2019.

resource.name: Property Assessment and Sales - FY20
resource.description: This dataset represents real estate assessment and sales data that is updated on a quarterly basis by the Real Estate Assessor’s Office. This dataset contains information for properties in the city including: Acreage, Square footage, GPIN, Street Address, year built, current land value, current improvement values, and current total value. The information is obtained from Real Estate Assessor’s Office ProVal records database.
resource.attribution: Norfolk Real Estate Assessor's Office

resource.name: Street Sweeping Schedule
resource.description:
The City of Norfolk’s street sweeping program is designed to remove pollutants such as oil, grease, nutrients, and sediment from the roadway before entering the stormwater system. It supports Norfolk’s initiative for cleaner waterways by reducing pollution and nuisance flooding, minimizing stormwater runoff, and collecting approximately 6,682 tons of debris per year.

While the goal of the program is to ensure street sweeping occurs once per month for all neighborhoods, the program is currently experiencing delays due to long lead times on equipment repairs, hiring challenges, and inclement weather. The street sweeping schedule will be temporarily revised to a quarterly rotation until equipment challenges can be addressed. Areas with enforcement signage will continue to be swept monthly, and parking enforcement will not be suspended during this time.

This dataset reflects the recent changes in the street sweeping schedule, and shows a listing of the dates that curb in front of Norfolk addresses will be swept. The dataset will be updated at the beginning of each calendar year or as the street sweeping schedule changes.
resource.attribution: Division of Environmental Storm Water Management
columns_description: Indicates whether there are enforcement signs ("Yes" or "No") specifying when the street will be swept in front of the address.
Indicates whether street sweeping in front of the address occurs on a "Daily," "Monthly," or "Quarterly" basis.

The scheduled date for street sweeping in front of the address. Note that actual sweeping may vary from this date due to specific conditions as listed on this webpage: https://www.norfolk.gov/2658/Street-Sweeping
The longitude coordinates of the address.
The latitude coordinates of the address.
The address of the curb area that will be swept.

resource.name: Norfolk 2020 American Community Survey Five-Year Estimates
resource.description:
This dataset contains the American Community Survey (ACS) five-year estimates for Norfolk, Virginia. According to the United States Census Bureau, the ACS is the premier source for detailed population and housing information about communities and the nation. Every year, the Census Bureau conducts a survey and creates estimates for demographic categories such as income, employment, poverty, race, ethnicity, housing, age, gender, internet access, vehicle access, and other topics. For census tracts, 5-year estimates are generated and released to the public. 
This dataset includes five-year estimates released in 2020 for census tracts in Norfolk, VA and will be updated annually with each new release of five-year estimates.
resource.attribution: United States Census Bureau

resource.name: Resident Survey 2022
resource.description:
The City of Norfolk is committed to using data to help inform decisions and allocate resources. One important source of data is input from residents about their priorities and satisfaction with the services we provide. Norfolk last conducted a citywide survey of residents in 2014.

To provide up-to-date information regarding resident priorities and satisfaction, Norfolk contracted with ETC institute to conduct a survey of residents. This survey was conducted in the fall of 2022; surveys were sent via the U.S. Postal Service and respondents were given the choice of responding by mail, online, or by telephone. This survey represents a random and statistically valid sample of residents from across the city. ETC Institute monitored responses and followed up to ensure all sections of the city were represented. An opportunity was also provided for residents not included in the random sample to take the survey and express their views. This dataset includes all survey data, excluding demographic data to protect privacy. This dataset will be updated every two years.
resource.attribution: ETC Institute
columns_description: The overall category that the survey question falls under.
Indicates if the survey respondent was selected for the random sample of Norfolk residents or responded via the general public survey link.
The Ward that the survey respondent lived in at the time of the survey.
The Superward that the survey respondent lived in at the time of the survey.
Indicates if the survey respondent responded via mail or web.
The survey question.
The number of responses, grouped by Response Method, Random Sample Survey, Ward, Superward, Question Category, Question, and Response.
The survey response.

The data comes from the city’s implementation of CentralSquare’s Enterprise Asset Management platform, also known as Lucity. This dataset is updated daily on weekdays.
resource.attribution: Departments of Parks and Recreation, Public Works, and Transportation

resource.name: FEMA NFIP Claims
resource.description:
First, a caveat: the NFIP data does NOT provide information specific to individual homes or parcels. This information is protected under federal law. All personal identifying information about policy holders has been redacted, and data has been anonymized to census tract, reported ZIP code, and one decimal point digit of latitute and longitude. If mapped, flood insurance policies and claims may appear to be clustered at a particular location due to this anonymization.
What all that means: you cannot search for an address to see whether it has flooded.
However, among many things, this data shows flooding trends in Norfolk over the last 40+ years. It shows the census tracts that flood most frequently. And it shows where the largest number and highest value of claims occur.

FEMA believes this historic release of NFIP data promotes transparency, reduces complexity related to public data requests, and improves how stakeholders interact with and understand the program. This is the largest, most comprehensive release of NFIP data coordinated by FEMA to date. This dataset allows for customizable searches to create reports, analyze and visualize present and historical NFIP data faster and easier than before. 
This data will help FEMA build a national culture of preparedness by providing claims and policy information people need to make better choices about their flood risk and the insurance they need to protect the life they've built. 
Norfolk's Open Data team extracted city-specific information from the FEMA dataset. The dataset included here represents almost 6,000 claims on record from 1977 through 2019, totaling 67 million dollars in damage in the City of Norfolk.
resource.attribution: FEMA
columns_name: Amount Paid On Increased Cost Of Compliance Claim
Number Of Floors In The Insured Building
Number of Floors in the Insured Buildings Definitions

resource.name: Property Assessment and Sales - FY19
resource.description: This dataset represents real estate assessment and sales data that is updated on a quarterly basis by the Real Estate Assessor’s Office. This dataset contains information for properties in the city including: Acreage, Square footage, GPIN, Street Address, year built, current land value, current improvement values, and current total value. The information is obtained from Real Estate Assessor’s Office ProVal records database
resource.attribution: Norfolk Real Estate Assessor’s Office

resource.name: Streetlight Upgrade Project
resource.description: This dataset contains information regarding Dominion Energy owned (city leased) streetlights that are designated for upgrades to LED bulbs, to improve dependability, light emission, reduce energy consumption, and improve nighttime public safety. The prioritization of the upgrades was determined using public safety information including calls for service and traffic accidents, as well as vehicular and pedestrian traffic levels.
resource.attribution: Department of Transportation

resource.name: Tree Planting Program
resource.description: Recreation, Parks and Open Space’s Bureau of Parks and Urban Forestry plants hundreds of trees each year along city streets, within city parks, and on other city properties.  This dataset gives pertinent tree species information, shows important geographic information about which parts of Norfolk are receiving trees in a given year, and historical data about planting date.  City staff utilizes Microsoft excel to track tree planting information. This dataset will show where the City of Norfolk plants its trees on city owned properties.  This data is updated annually.
resource.attribution: Steven Traylor, City Forester; Parks and Forestry Operations, Recreation, Parks and Open Spaces

resource.name: Norfolk Animal Care and Adoption Center (NACC)
resource.description: The Norfolk Animal Care and Adoption Center (NACC) is the city’s animal sheltering facility. The NACC is an open-admission shelter; animals are never turned away, regardless of species, age, health or temperament.  This data reports on an animal from the moment it arrives at the shelter (intake) to the moment it leaves (outcome).  It also reports on foster activities.  This data is updated monthly.

resource.name: Adoptions
resource.description:
This dataset contains demographic and case characteristics of children in foster care in Norfolk with the goal of adoption.  The dataset includes the sex, age, race, placement, parental rights status and adoption status of these children. The data is from Virginia’s Online Automated Services Information System (OASIS).  OASIS is a comprehensive system that tracks the day-to-day activities performed by social workers statewide and is the official case record system for foster care and adoption cases in Virginia.  

This dataset details the work accomplished by staff at the Norfolk Department of Human Services with the goal of finding safe, permanent homes for children in Norfolk’s foster care system. This dataset is updated monthly.
resource.attribution: Deanna Powell-Brickhouse, Department of Human Services

resource.name: Fleet
resource.description:
This dataset provides data about the assets that are managed by the Division of Fleet Management.  Assets fall into two categories: vehicle or equipment.  

Fleet Management uses a point system that considers a variety of factors to determine which assets are recommended for replacement.   An asset with 15 points or higher is recommended for replacement.
resource.attribution: Tanisha Brown, Fleet Management, Department of General Services

resource.name: Mental Health, Intellectual/Developmental Disabilities, and Substance Use Disorder Services
resource.description:
Norfolk Community Services Board (CSB) is the primary provider of public mental health, substance abuse, intellectual /developmental disabilities and substance use disorder in Norfolk, VA.  The continuum of services provided by the CSB spans from outreach and prevention through intensive psychiatric care.  CSB services are provided by clinical service professionals with expertise in these service areas.

This dataset is a monthly breakdown of certain services that CSB provides Norfolk’s residents. These services include mental health, developmental, substance abuse, and emergency services. These services do not make up all the services that CSB provides, that include services such as infant and toddler and specific grant-funded services. A total hourly duration for the month is provided, as well as details on the type of service that was provided. This dataset will be updated monthly.
resource.attribution: Norfolk Community Services Board
columns_description: The general description/categorization of the service provided by Community Services Board (CSB).

Denotes if the area of care was a mental health service, developmental service, emergency or ancillary service, or a substance use disorder service. An individual may be provided with multiple service areas, but only one is listed per client as part of the monthly aggregation.
Total duration (in hours) during the month of the service provided. This data only includes services that track in hours.
City of Norfolk cost center code for financial tracking of the CSB program providing the service. This data does not include any special revenue accounts.
Month and year that the service was provided.

Denotes if a service was a direct service (face-to-face service with a client) or a client related service (any service associated with a specific client, such as treatment planning or reaching out to a client’s provider).

resource.name: Micromobility (Electric Scooters and Bikes)
resource.description: This dataset is data about trips on electric scooters and electric-assisted bikes. Lime scooters were made available to the public in June 2019 to use throughout Norfolk, and Lime e-bikes were made available to the public in June 2021. Data represents trips from July 2019 to the present and is updated weekly.
resource.attribution: Dorian Allen, Department of Transportation

resource.name: Bike and Pedestrian Trip Counts
resource.description: Bike and pedestrian counters have been installed at six locations along the Elizabeth River Trail and at 15 locations along Norfolk’s existing bike lanes to accurately track pedestrian and cyclist use along the trail and bike network. This counter system combines the passive infrared sensor to count pedestrians on the adjacent sidewalk and an inductive loop sensor to detect bicycles in existing bike lanes. This dataset comprises data from two types of counters – Eco-Counter and Roadsys. The Eco-Counter data begins in April 2019 and is updated quarterly. The Roadsys data begins in April 2021 and is updated quarterly.
resource.attribution: Anna Dewey, Department of Transportation
columns_description: Type of counter
Latitude location of the counter
Location of the counter
Longitude location of the counter
Date that the counter collected data
Number of bikes that passed the counter
Number of pedestrians that passed the counter

resource.name: Norfolk Master Street List
resource.description: Information containing the master list of valid street names in the City.  Street names may include a directional that is fully spelled out (i.e., East, West, North, or South) depending on how the street name was legally recorded. Those streets with a pre-directional (i.e., N, S, E, W) before the street name will be listed twice in this index, once under the first letter of the street name and again using the pre-direction. For example, W Brambleton Avenue will be listed both under W and under B. Street status field also indicates where a street is located: city, military base, or crosses over both military base and city.
resource.attribution: Department of Information Technology
columns_description: A component that qualifies the street name by type of street such as AVE(Avenue), DR (Drive), or RD (Road).
Status as to where the Street is located: City, Base, City & Base, Paper, Private.
Directional word found as last word in the street name and there is no other directional to the right of it.
A component that qualifies the street name by type of street such as AVE(Avenue), DR (Drive), or RD (Road).
The primary name field that identifies the street.  Street names can be words or numbers.
Full Street Name
Directional word found as the first word in the street name and there is no other directional to the left of it.

resource.name: Better Buildings Challenge Properties
resource.description:
This dataset contains information pertaining to the Better Buildings Challenge, an initiative created by the U.S. Department of Energy with the objective of reducing overall energy consumption. Aligned with the City of Norfolk’s Climate Action Plan, the City Council adopted a resolution in 2022 to achieve a 20% reduction in energy consumption by the year 2032 across 127 selected properties within Norfolk’s building portfolio, totaling approximately 6,000,000 square feet. This action solidified Norfolk’s commitment to the Better Buildings Challenge.

This dataset utilizes data from 2019 as the baseline year. Energy tracking tools, specifically EnergyCAP and EnergySTAR Portfolio Manager, are utilized to measure various metrics related to energy usage in the 127 properties. The primary indicators in the dataset for tracking energy consumption are the Source Energy Use (in kBtu) and the Source Energy Use Units (energy use per square foot). While the dataset covers metrics from 2019 to the present, the Better Buildings Challenge excludes data from 2020 and 2021 (due to COVID) when evaluating progress toward the 20% reduction goal by 2032. This dataset will be updated monthly.
resource.attribution: U.S. Department of Energy
columns_name: Percent Difference from National Median Source Energy Use Units
National Median Source Energy Use Units
National Median Site Energy Use Units
columns_description: The year in which the property was constructed.
A unique identifier number assigned by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to the property.
For mapping purposes, showing the geographic point of the property.

This column was automatically created in order to record in what polygon from the dataset 'Civic Leagues' (x6fk-ihs5) the point in column 'geographic_point' is located.  This enables the creation of region maps (choropleths) in the visualization canvas and data lens.

This column was automatically created in order to record in what polygon from the dataset 'US Counties' (25t2-rbz7) the point in column 'geographic_point' is located.  This enables the creation of region maps (choropleths) in the visualization canvas and data lens.
The longitude coordinate of the property.
The Energy Cost divided by the Gross Floor Area.
The total cost, in dollars of the property’s energy use for the 12-month time period.
The percentage difference for between the property’s source energy use units and the national median.
The national median source energy use units.
The national median source energy use.
The Source Energy Use divided by the Gross Floor Area. Source Energy Use Units is the best way to quantify the energy performance of properties.

The total amount of raw fuel that is required to operate the property. In addition to what the property consumes on-site, source energy includes losses that take place during generation, transmission, and distribution of the energy, thereby enabling a complete assessment of energy consumption resulting from building operations. Expressed in kBTUs (one-thousand British thermal units). For more information, see this link: https://portfoliomanager.energystar.gov/pm/glossary#SourceEnergy
The national median site energy use units.

The national median site energy use of similar properties in Energy Star Portfolio Manager. 50% of properties nationwide perform below the median, and 50% perform above the median. For more information, see this link: https://portfoliomanager.energystar.gov/pm/glossary#NationalMedian
The Site Energy Use divided by the Gross Floor Area.

The annual amount of all the energy the property consumes on site, regardless of source (electrical, natural gas, etc.). It includes energy purchased from the grid or in bulk, as well as renewable energy generated and consumed on-site. Expressed in kBTUs (one-thousand British thermal units).

The last day of a 12-month period on which a set of metrics are based. This date starts on the first day of one month and ends 12 months later on the last day of the last month (e.g., 6/1/2013 – 5/31/2014). All metrics in this dataset are calculated based on 12 full calendar months of data.
Indicates the total number of buildings that are located on the property.
Indicates the primary use of the property, such as “Courthouse”, “Stadium (Open)”, “Office”, “Fire Station”, among others.
The name of the property as defined by the City of Norfolk.
The total property square footage, including if there is  more than one building on the property.
The latitude coordinate of the property.
The address location of the property.
